title: China Evergrande's EV Business to Raise $347 Million From Share Sales
summary: The cash-strapped Chinese property developer's Evergrande Auto unit is aiming to bolster its financial position and fund EV production.. title: When Should You Get a Covid-19 Booster Shot?
summary: With Thanksgiving gatherings and travel ahead for many, here are science-backed answers for when to time the shot for optimal protection. As eligibility for Covid-19 boosters widens in parts of the U.S., some people wonder when they should time their shots to maximize protection.

title: Airlines Gird for Thanksgiving Travel Test After Rocky Year
summary: Some 20 million people likely to pass through U.S. airports, testing system strained by short staffing and heavy traffic to leisure destinations. Thanksgiving will test whether airlines have done enough to insulate their operations from shocks that have roiled air travel in recent months.

title: Aurora, Colo., to Pay Elijah McClain's Family $15 Million Over His Death
summary: City Council approved settlement at July meeting, but financial details had to be finalized. The family of Elijah McClain, an unarmed 23-year-old Black man who died after an encounter with the police in Aurora, Colo., will receive a $15 million settlement with the city.

title: 2021 Holiday Gift Guide: All the Gift Ideas You'll Need
summary: We've got all kinds of gift guides for you-for all kinds of loved ones, from fashion fans to foodies, travel nuts to design enthusiasts, and even the nerdy gearheads on your list. And nearly everything is under $300.. LAST YEAR, facing a somber holiday season, we told our gift guide readers to resist "lizard-covered cocktail spoons" and other "silly" fare. This year...well, we're still not quite ready to bring on the reptilian flatware, but concepts like whimsy, fun and a little impracticality seem apropos again. Our discerning editors have rounded up 47 gift ideas under $300-from modern cuckoo clocks and bulldog-shaped ice cubes to a deconstructed BlackBerry amusingly memorialized in a frame-that strike the right note for a decidedly more festive, optimistic Noel.

title: As Joe Biden Turns 79, a Panic Over Kamala Harris
summary: He's unlikely to run in 2024, and his VP is deeply unpopular.. President Biden's 79th birthday Saturday is the key to understanding the Democratic alarms this week about Vice President Kamala Harris. Is her approval rating as terrible as the surveys say? Is she being unfairly sidelined by the White House? That fretting is really about Joe and 2024.

title: Kyle Rittenhouse Is Not Guilty
summary: The jury decides on the facts, but politicians continue to distort the truth.. The saga of Kyle Rittenhouse has shown the extent of America's political polarization. But the not guilty verdict returned by 12 unanimous jurors in his Kenosha, Wis. murder trial Friday shows that when presented deliberately with evidence and forced to reason with one another, Americans can still agree on basic facts.

title: The Northeast Climate Pact Implodes
summary: Connecticut Governor Lamont withdraws amid soaring fuel prices.. Progressives say the only way to achieve their climate goals is to raise the price of fossil fuels. Their problem is that consumers don't want to pay more for energy, and as the latest proof behold Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont's retreat this week from a Northeast state climate pact.

The top challenge: China's global ambitions and increasing belligerence toward Taiwan.

summary: After a rough primary campaign, he proved a loyal vice president and even succeeded Reagan.. title: Alex Murdaugh Indicted on 27 Counts of New Financial Crimes
summary: Indictments allege disgraced South Carolina lawyer defrauded victims and laundered more than $4.8 million. Alex Murdaugh, the disgraced South Carolina lawyer who is facing charges of swindling his late housekeeper's sons out of millions of dollars in an insurance settlement, has been indicted on new financial-crimes charges.A South Carolina grand jury issued five indictments, totaling 27 counts, that include breach of trust with fraudulent intent, obtaining signature or property by false pretenses, money laundering, computer crimes and forgery, Attorney General Alan Wilson said Friday."Altogether, Murdaugh is charged with respect to alleged schemes to defraud victims and thereafter launder $4,853,488.09," the attorney general said.

title: Iranian Hackers Broke Into Newspaper Publisher Lee Enterprises Ahead of 2020 Election
summary: Computer systems of Lee Enterprises, which owns dozens of daily papers, were targeted in disinformation campaign. WASHINGTON-Iranian hackers last year infiltrated the computer systems of Lee Enterprises Inc., a major American media company that publishes dozens of daily newspapers across the U.S., as part of a broader effort to spread disinformation about the 2020 presidential election, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Ford Scraps Plan to Develop an Electric Vehicle With Rivian
summary: The auto makers mutually decided to focus on their own projects, backing away from an earlier strategic pact. Ford Motor Co. and Rivian Automotive Inc. have decided to go their separate ways rather than collaborate on future electric vehicles, backing away from an earlier strategic pact that led to a multibillion-dollar windfall for Ford.

title: Gift Guide 2021: The Best Books to Buy This Holiday Season
summary: To find the perfect presents for all the readers in your life, our seasonal guide has you covered.. A book is perhaps the most enduring gift we can offer the people in our lives: a source of entertainment or knowledge, recipes or reflections. A solace or an inside joke, a message that says "I know what you like" or "Here's an interest we can share." Once again, we've asked frequent contributors to these pages to help assemble a guide to gift-giving-for readers of all tastes and ages.

summary: Covid-19 concerns in Europe cloud prospects for global economic recovery. U.S. stocks closed mixed Friday. Investors piled into the safety of the dollar and government bonds after fresh Covid-19 restrictions in Europe clouded prospects for the global economic recovery.

summary: Three white Georgia men stand trial for murder in the death of a Black man, Ahmaud Arbery. The trial of the three white Georgia men charged in the murder of Ahmaud Arbery, a Black man, began Nov. 5. in Brunswick, Ga.

summary: Nvidia, Qualcomm and AMD are all up more than 30% over the past month, far outpacing the S&P 500. But it has been great news lately for investors in semiconductor stocks, some of which have been performing at the top of the S&P 500 over the past month.

title: The Art Market Surges, Selling $2.3 Billion in Works
summary: Resume Subscription. The art market is sizzling. The world's chief auction houses sold more than $2.3 billion worth of art during a two-week sale series in New York that ends Friday. Back in person en masse for the first time since early 2019, collectors chased after high-end art with a voraciousness not seen since a few years before the pandemic.

title: Comrade Omarova vs. Margaret Thatcher
summary: Some aspiring apparatchiks will say anything to seize power.. President Joe Biden's nominee to oversee most of the banking assets in the United States had a rocky confirmation hearing in the Senate on Thursday. Readers of Journal editorials know comptroller of the currency nominee Saule Omarova as the activist who has spoken in glowing terms about the idea of a Federal Reserve takeover of consumer bank deposits and also bankrupting fossil-fuel companies.

title: Make Mine Marvel
summary: The endlessly recombining narratives of Marvel comics have their roots in cheap entertainment, but they offer a multiverse of stories.. From the early 1960s to today, the world of Marvel superheroes has seen its fan base grow from an inner circle of comic-book addicts to, well, seemingly everybody. Beginning with the first issue of The Fantastic Four, in 1961, readers have followed the serialized adventures of characters who possess both extra-human abilities and the quintessentially human quality of vulnerability. The bitter, rock-skinned, immensely strong Thing of the Fantastic Four; the green-skinned, enraged, even more immensely strong Hulk; and, especially, the perpetually tormented Spider-Man-these are among the often confused, not-always-heroic heroes whose adventures drew an increasingly sophisticated readership during a decade that brought real-world confusion of its own. Some have observed that with the expansion of Marvel's universe over the decades, particularly through the many recent top-grossing movies based on the comic books, Marvel has moved from the counterculture deep into the culture itself, becoming a colossal, ongoing, near-mythological epic made up of many, many characters whose narrative arcs frequently intertwine in fascinating, sometimes bewildering ways. Latecomers, especially moviegoers who want to read the comics for a deeper understanding of the "cinematic universe" they have come to love, may ask: Where do I start?

title: 'Chanel No. 5' Review: Catching Lightning in a Bottle
summary: Coco Chanel wanted a signature perfume to accompany her modern fashions. It became unstoppable.. Every 30 seconds, someone somewhere in the world buys a bottle of Chanel No. 5, the French government declared in 2006, a claim that has often been repeated. Whether it's still true, or if it ever was, is a company secret, as Chanel's sales figures were private until 2017. What is certain is that "le monstre," as Chanel No. 5 is known in the industry, has been a sensation from the moment it appeared in 1921. Coco Chanel created it with the expert "nose" Ernest Beaux as a complement to her radical new fashion. She wanted a fresh, abstract scent that, like her little black dresses, epitomized modern allure.

title: McKinsey Paying $18 Million to Settle SEC Investigation Over Insider-Trading Controls
summary: Partners oversaw investments in companies that were also firm's consulting clients. WASHINGTON-McKinsey & Co. has agreed to pay $18 million to settle allegations that it didn't adequately guard against the risk of insider trading involving investments in companies for which the firm was also a consultant.

title: Two Fed Officials Weigh Prospect of Speeding Bond-Buying Taper Process
summary: Fed Vice Chairman Clarida and Fed governor Waller point to inflation, strong economy in separate appearances. Two Federal Reserve governors opened the door on Friday to the possibility the central bank could move more swiftly to end its asset-buying stimulus effort.

title: The Impossible Insurrection of January 6
summary: The right couldn't stage a coup because liberals dominate nearly every institution of American politics and culture. Yet liberals refuse to see it.. After the Capitol riot of Jan. 6, the New York Times and other publications on the left began calling the event an "insurrection" and an attempted "coup." The riot was an appalling and dishonorable event, and the perpetrators of its crimes are rightly being prosecuted. But to call it an attempted coup is preposterous-and not simply for the practical reason that the prosecuted rioters weren't indicted for treason or conspiracy to overthrow the government but for obstruction of an official proceeding, trespassing on government property, disorderly conduct and the like. The idea that Donald Trump and his followers had any chance of overthrowing the U.S. government, or even that they aimed at that outcome, is a delusion. That delusion springs from American liberal elites' failure to accept the fact of their own predominance.

title: How Harris Became First Woman to Serve as Acting President
summary: President Biden briefly transferred power to the vice president while he underwent a routine colonoscopy. President Biden briefly transferred power to Vice President Kamala Harris Friday while he was under anesthesia during a routine colonoscopy, making her the first woman to serve as acting president in U.S. history. Here's what that means:

title: Chernin Entertainment Taps Advisers to Explore Options
summary: Studio is working with investment banks Moelis and Centerview to weigh options including sale of a stake. Chernin Entertainment, the studio behind movies and TV shows including "Fear Street" and the "Planet of the Apes" reboot series, has tapped bankers to explore options including a sale of a stake in the business or other equity partnership, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Crypto as Elusive as a Knicks NBA Championship
summary: New York's 'BitLicense' means its sports fans can watch teams play in venues named after companies with forbidden offerings. When New York's teams play someday at the soon-to-be named Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles, their fans and players who live in the Empire State will be able enjoy all the stadium has to offer, except for one thing: its sponsor's services.

title: 'When Women Ruled the World' Review: Blasts of the Trumpet
summary: Were 16th-century monarchs like Elizabeth I and her Scots cousin rivals-or subtle allies in a world of men?. In 1558, John Knox, the energetically tub-thumping Scottish reformer, railed against what would become even more true with the coronation of Elizabeth of England, the future Gloriana herself, a few months later: the unlikely and-to him-hideous rush of women into positions of supreme power in late 16th-century Europe. The cards of the game of birthright were serially falling in a female direction.

title: U.K. Soccer Stadiums Design for Safer Standing at Games
summary: Five British soccer clubs will test sections designed to safely satisfy spectators' desire to stand and cheer. British soccer teams are poised to begin a test that could allow passionate fans to once again stand up during matches without breaking the rules. The U.K. government is backing a trial of "safe standing" areas, in which new railings separate rows to prevent fans from falling forward.

title: Matisse in Baltimore
summary: The Baltimore Museum of Art is opening an intimate study center devoted to the work of the French master. The Baltimore Museum of Art is home to a large and highly acclaimed collection of art by Henri Matisse. Now the BMA is giving the great French artist a starring role in an ambitious new museum-wide initiative. Opening Dec. 12, the Ruth R. Marder Center for Matisse Studies offers an intimate counterpoint to the wide-ranging Matisse shows that BMA visitors know and love. It has space for small, focused exhibitions and a study room/library that, starting next spring, will be open by appointment to students, scholars, artists and members of the public. "I see this as a quieter place to do some really close looking," said the center's director, curator Katy Rothkopf-particularly at the drawings, prints and other works on paper that comprise most of the museum's 1,200-plus Matisse holdings, many of them rarely shown.

title: 'Magritte' Review: This Is Not a Book Review
summary: Surrealism, in the hands of Salvador Dalí, was a wild performance. René Magritte made it a clever, cool trick.. The Surrealists talked a good picture, and René Magritte was more a visual punster than a virtuoso painter. His art, Alex Danchev writes in this thoroughly and gruesomely entertaining biography, is "a cross between Wittgenstein's thought and Alice in Wonderland, with a seasoning of surrealism, a pinch of eroticism, and a sizzle of dread." All true, all gripping, but not primarily pictorial. Still, Mr. Danchev is right to call Magritte "the dream merchant of our time." Magritte's studiously underplayed paintings are a modern image bank, and we draw on it unknowingly every time we see the Apple logo.

title: 'Powder Days' Review: A View From the Top
summary: A ski bum from the old days remembers the original ruggedness-a realm requiring 'skill and nerve.'. She spent her first winter at Beaver Creek, the Colorado ski resort, in an employee housing unit whose rooms showed disturbing signs of black mold. Single beds predominated, though we might assume that chastity didn't. The life was spartan, it was minimalist, it was primitive. And it was great.

title: 'These Precious Days' Review: Friendship, Mortality, Clutter
summary: In these essays, there's a freshness, an openness, that never gets near oversharing-and a humanity that never gets near sanctimony.. Ann Patchett was 26 when, for the first time, she began thinking about her demise. She was working on her first novel-seven have since followed, including "Bel Canto," "Commonwealth" and "The Dutch House"-and she hadn't made an outline, hadn't jotted down any notes, hadn't considered exigencies. What if, during a swim in the chilly Atlantic (a favorite activity), she got cramps (a frequent affliction) and couldn't make it back to shore (a constant nightmare). What then?

title: Elizabeth Holmes's Trial Reaches Turning Point: Will She Testify?
summary: As the government finishes its case, the Theranos founder must weigh the potential risks and rewards of speaking for herself. Elizabeth Holmes will soon face a big decision: whether to testify in her own defense in a bid to escape a criminal-fraud conviction.

title: Ryanair to Drop London Listing in Wake of Brexit
summary: Europe's largest budget airline seeks to cut costs, comply with EU ownership rules. LONDON-Europe's largest budget airline, Ryanair Holdings PLC, plans to ditch its London listing, citing low trading volumes and a desire to accelerate efforts to comply with European Union ownership requirements.

title: Model Refashioned Herself to Raise Three Sons
summary: Carmen Collins, who has died at age 69, moved to the Chicago suburbs in search of better schools, safer streets and a career in real estate. As a high-school student on Chicago's South Side in the late 1960s, Carmen Leon noticed that Black women were starting to appear as models in mainstream publications. It looked like an opportunity.

title: Thinking About Traveling this Christmas? A Guide to Last-Minute Holiday Vacations
summary: For a last-minute getaway, try one of these five festive and less predictable locales. CURVEBALLS, from the Delta variant to supply chain snafus, may be threatening the holidays. If procrastination or the many disruptions of 2021 mean you're only now planning a seasonal getaway, consider these five wonderful-in-winter destinations where bookings are still available and room rates won't break the bank.

title: Boeing Dreamliner Defects Bog Down Production
summary: Plane maker further slows production as door-area issue proves difficult to address, delaying deliveries and complicating airlines' plans. Boeing Co. has further slowed production of 787 Dreamliners as it addresses defects that are delaying deliveries of new jets and complicating airlines' plans, people familiar with the matter said.

title: As Dixie Fire Raged, California Man Allegedly Set Four New Wildfires Nearby
summary: Former college professor charged with arson to federal property and setting timber on fire. A federal grand jury indicted a former California college professor after he allegedly sparked four wildfires near the massive Dixie Fire this summer that threatened firefighters and first responders.

title: Pastor Frank Williams Has a Calling to 'Become Part of the Solution'
summary: In a time of controversies, a Bronx minister steers the Southern Baptist Convention's National African American Fellowship. As a child in Bronx, N.Y., in the 1980s, pastor Frank Williams dutifully went to church with his mother and grandmother every Sunday. "I didn't know it was Southern Baptist," he recalls. "It was just our church."

title: The Great Shopping Reset: How the Pandemic Helped Fix Retail
summary: With less to sell than usual, department stores and specialty chains were able to rein in discounts and charge more, boosting profits. The Covid-19 pandemic was supposed to deliver a knockout punch to department stores and specialty retailers. Instead, many of them are bouncing back healthier.

title: 'Flashes of Creation' Review: A Universal Debate
summary: The concept of the big bang has become widely accepted in a relatively short while.. The idea that there was a definite beginning to the universe as we know it, at a time we can calculate, is well established in the public imagination. It may therefore come as a shock to be reminded that the idea itself-the big bang-is less than a century old, and that the acceptance of the idea as the best explanation for our observations of the cosmos is little more than 50.

title: Noonan, 'Wokeness,' and Democrats in Peril
summary: Neither party can afford to alienate the moderate center.. What exactly is it about wokeness that has evoked such a reaction? Its premise, that there is much racism in U.S. history and in American biases, conscious and unconscious, is not controversial. Who could deny that slavery, Jim Crow and de jure and de facto segregation were not racist, or would argue that their effects could have disappeared entirely?

title: Answering the Critics of National Conservatism
summary: The assault on nationhood, the dissolution of cultural norms and the paradoxes of market globalization demand new solutions.. Regarding Matthew Continetti's and Rafael Hoffman's letters (Nov. 17) about my op-ed "Why America Needs National Conservatism" (Nov. 13): I devoted half the article to the challenge of sustaining American nationhood in the face of a concerted political assault. How can it be said, as Mr. Continetti does, that the term "national" is surplusage in "national conservatism," with no role in my arguments?

title: Government Wants Credit for Moderna's Covid Vaccine
summary: It is an unfortunate tendency of regulators to develop the self-delusion that they create what they regulate and must seize control of it.. I appreciate the tremendous effort made by Moderna innovators ("Ganging Up on Moderna" (Review and Outlook, Nov. 17) and happily received the company's vaccine and booster. It is an unfortunate tendency of those who regulate pharmaceuticals to develop the self-delusion that they create what they regulate and must seize control of it. Those who want to live must not be sacrificed to such a destructive political ideology.

title: The Annuity Option for a Secure Retirement
summary: Payout annuities provide more in annual income from $1 million than either a 4% withdrawal strategy or a 3.3%.. "Weekend Investor: The 4% Nest Egg Rule Is Cracking" (Exchange, Nov. 13) raises the question: Where's the annuity? Easy-to-find online annuity calculators show payout annuities today providing more in annual income from $1 million than either a 4% withdrawal strategy or a 3.3% withdrawal plan in early retirement years. That's the case whether the annuitant is male or female or takes a straight annuity on his or her life or as a two-part annuity with another person, like a spouse or partner.

title: Two Democrats Oppose Powell for Fed Chair, Citing Climate Change
summary: Progressive Democrats have split over potential reappointment of Jerome Powell; Biden set to announce pick soon. Two liberal Democratic senators said Friday they would oppose a second term for Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell because they want the central bank to play a more aggressive role addressing climate change.

title: Lunar Eclipse Photos: See the Beaver Moon Up Close
summary: Resume Subscription. A partial lunar eclipse took place early Friday morning, the longest of its kind in 581 years.

title: SoftBank Vision Fund CFO Cautions Not All Investments Will Be the Next DoorDash. Many Are Likely to Fail
summary: Navneet Govil talks about China, crypto and the technology investor's losses amid recent market volatility. SoftBank Group Corp.'s Vision Fund has poured billions of dollars into startups and later-stage companies. After recovering last year from losses related to the coronavirus pandemic, the fund suffered in recent months after Chinese regulators cracked down on a range of consumer-facing businesses that hurt SoftBank's investments in companies such as ride hailing company Didi Global Inc. The fund-via its Fund I and Fund II-holds stakes in about 250 companies. Navneet Govil, the CFO of the Vision Fund, this week invited the finance chiefs of some portfolio companies to California. Edited excerpts follow.

title: IPOs Keep Jumping Higher. How Long Will the Ride Last?
summary: Valuations are frothy, market debuts are splashy and everyone's got a SPAC. After decades, the roster of public companies is growing. That could mean big changes for business.. Last week, an electric-vehicle maker that had delivered just 156 trucks went public in an initial offering that made it more valuable than Ford Motor Co. The week before, a money-losing sneaker company was worth nearly $4 billion at the end of its first day of public trading.

title: Surprise Winners From Biden's $2 Trillion Spending Bill: Wall Street and Tobacco Companies
summary: Tobacco companies, banks and private-equity firms are among winners, although package still includes increased levies. title: Popular Tax Trick for Savers Is Eliminated in House Bill
summary: Democrats are backing efforts to prevent the wealthiest Americans from shielding multimillion-dollar retirement accounts from taxes. Americans would no longer be able to use some popular strategies to move money into tax-free Roth individual retirement accounts under a roughly $2 trillion education, healthcare and climate package House Democrats approved on Friday.

title: Wall Street Fines Fall 18% in First Year of Biden Administration
summary: Securities and Exchange Commission obtains $3.9 billion in enforcement sanctions. WASHINGTON-Enforcement fines levied against Wall Street firms and public companies fell 18% in the first year of the Biden administration, according to newly released statistics.

title: Teamsters Union Elects Sean O'Brien as New Leader
summary: The election comes at a time when public support for unions is at its highest in decades. Members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters this week elected Sean O'Brien as the union's new general president by a wide margin, a victory that will formally bring an end to the reign of James P. Hoffa.

title: Los Angeles Home of Thomson Reuters Publishing Heiress Hits the Market for $43 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. Media and publishing heiress Taylor Thomson, a member of one of Canada's wealthiest families, is listing her Los Angeles mansion for $43 million.

title: Five Principles for a Better Post-Pandemic You
summary: Covid has worsened the stress and isolation of modern life, but a few simple ideas can put us on the path to well-being.. As an executive coach, I saw a troubling trend among my clients even before Covid-19: Many were exhausted and on a path to burnout, if they weren't already there.

title: 'Our First Civil War' Review: Friends, Enemies, Countrymen
summary: For Ben Franklin's son and others who rejected rebellion, the core value was loyalty to the king. Who were the traitors?. For eight months in 1777, an American Loyalist-pledging continued allegiance to the British crown in the early stages of the American Revolution-found himself in solitary confinement in Connecticut's infamous Litchfield jail. His food came poked through a hole in the door. "Debarred," he later wrote, of "Pen, Ink, and Paper," he found that his sole human intercourse was the rare scraps of talk he could wring from his jailers. It was as if he had been "buried alive." There was neither seat, nor bed, nor toilet-just a straw-covered floor. The prisoner would eventually lose his teeth and hair. "I should deem it a favor," he wrote to Jonathan Trumbull, Connecticut's Patriot governor, "to be immediately taken out and shot." He was not executed but rather, exchanged for the captured rebel leader of Delaware, saw out the war in New York City, a Loyalist stronghold that would stay in British hands until November 1783, two years after Yorktown.

title: Destruction of Brazilian Amazon Surges to 15-Year High
summary: Environmentalists accuse government of withholding deforestation data from this month's COP26 climate summit. SÃO PAULO-Deforestation in the Brazilian Amazon rainforest has reached a 15-year high, newly released data shows. The surge is prompting environmentalists and scientists to question the government's willingness to meet the pledge it made at the COP26 climate summit earlier this month to end illegal woodlands destruction by 2028.

title: Cuba's Protest Anthem Wins Top Awards at Latin Grammys
summary: The worldwide hit is banned in Cuba and one of its composers is in a high-security prison. "Patria y Vida," the rap song that has become the anthem for disaffected Cubans, won two Latin Grammy awards for song of the year and best urban song, shining a spotlight on the struggle for freedom of expression in the Communist island and the harsh imprisonment of one of its authors.

title: Starbucks Union Drive Is Spreading From Buffalo to Arizona
summary: Store managers in Buffalo area have left as unionization efforts press on; workers in Mesa, Ariz., are now looking to unionize. Efforts by Starbucks Corp . workers to unionize have spread to Arizona, while stores in the Buffalo, N.Y., area have seen a shake-up in leadership amid the union drive there.

title: Rittenhouse Deliberations Move Into Fourth Day, With Few Clues From Jury
summary: The jury has been deliberating since Tuesday and has revealed little on the direction it may be leaning. Jury deliberations stretched into a fourth day Friday in the trial of Kyle Rittenhouse, the teenager who killed two people during unrest in Kenosha, Wis., last year, with few signs of which direction the panel might be heading.

title: Trimming Your Stocks Without Triggering the IRS
summary: How to minimize exposure and keep your investment plan on course while stocks are booming. With the S&P 500 up 27% so far this year after gaining 18% in 2020, you might have more exposure to stocks than you want.

title: 'Brothers in Arms' Review: Britons on the Beach
summary: On D-Day, the Sherwood Rangers launched the liberation of France led by its leading tank, dubbed Robin Hood.. Popular military histories usually build their homes in one of three crowded subdivisions: Big Battles, Big Leaders or Front-line Survival. Front-line survival stories, whether Erich Maria Remarque's masterpiece, "All Quiet on the Western Front" (1928), or Adam Makos's modern "Spearhead" (2019), offer a granular view of battle: flying bullets, arms blown off, limits tested. The other two subgenres sacrifice close-up action for epic scope.

title: Soggy French Fries? Blame the Cooking Oil Price Spike. 'It's Pretty Much Liquid Gold.'
summary: Resume Subscription. If your french fries are tasting funny these days, it might be the oil.

title: Covid-19 Treatments: What Is FDA Approved and What Is Coming Next?
summary: Monoclonal antibody drugs are authorized for emergency use, while Pfizer and Merck's pill regimens are under review. The FDA authorized the first Covid-19 vaccine for emergency use in December 2020 and drugmakers haven't slowed down since. According to the FDA, hundreds of Covid-19 treatments are being studied. The treatments include antivirals and antibody therapies that keep the virus from multiplying, immunomodulators that alter the body's immune response to the virus and pills that clear the virus in recently diagnosed patients. Here's what we have to prevent and treat Covid-19 as of Nov. 19.

title: Reading on the Wing: A Flock of Bird Books
summary: Science and imagination take flight together in these books dedicated to the inhabitants of the skies.. A lovely fresco painted about 3,500 years ago on the island of Santorini, Greece, shows a pair of swallows dancing in the air, their beaks about to touch as they whirl around. It is spring, and the lilies sprouting from the rocks below and beside the birds look as if they wanted to reach toward them, eager for a share in that lightness. Birds can go wherever they want, muses Boria Sax in "Avian Illuminations," his wide-ranging, wistful history of human connections with the bird world, from the first drawings on cave walls to Rachel Carson's dire warnings. Some birds may beat their wings, some might just prefer to let themselves be carried by the wind. It is almost impossible, writes Mr. Sax, "to imagine this sort of freedom."

title: 'Principles for Dealing With the Changing World Order' Review: Trouble Ahead, As Usual
summary: The ineluctable 'cycles' of history are said to explain everything, if you can attain a lofty enough perspective.. Four years ago, Ray Dalio threw at us a great big book of windy wisdom called "Principles." He defined the title word as "fundamental truths that serve as the foundations for behavior that gets you what you want out of life," a definition that seemed to promise a great deal, given that the author was the founder of Bridgewater Associates, the planet's biggest hedge fund. The book was a treatise on the means to a successful life, written by a man so accustomed to being "admired and, above all, consulted" (to cite Zola on a character from his novel "Money") that Mr. Dalio was apparently unfazed by his lack of expertise in ethics or philosophy. Faintly absurd was the fact that "Principles" doesn't contain a single name in its index. Given its title, you'd have expected, at least, Aristotle, the Buddha, Christ or Spinoza.

title: 'The Impossible Art' Review: Where Performance and Music Collide
summary: For Matthew Aucoin, opera is the place where multiple artforms wrestle-with exciting and unpredictable results.. For a long time, people have condemned opera as elitist, irrelevant or moribund, an expensive spectacle catering to well-heeled and well-dressed crowds. Now more than ever, this hard-to-produce, hard-to-justify medium is under scrutiny. Older audiences want the tried and true-the ABC of "Aida," "Bohème" and "Carmen"-while hipper, younger ones thrill to different kinds of musical and dramatic idioms.

title: 'A Light in the Dark' Review: Cut to the Directors
summary: David Thomson celebrates the figures behind the camera, while Peter Conrad pans across 'The Mysteries of Cinema.'. Good critics have the ability to compel you, even toward artists you are not particularly interested in. They can also make you reconsider your own opinions. David Thomson is best known as the author of the invaluable "A Biographical Dictionary of Cinema," originally published in 1975 and now in its sixth edition; he also wrote "Showman," his 1992 model biography of the producer David O. Selznick. He is assuredly one of our finest critics.

title: Five Best: Books on Thanksgiving Dinner
summary: Selected by Melanie Kirkpatrick, the author, most recently, of 'Lady Editor: Sarah Josepha Hale and the Making of the Modern American Woman.'. By Edward Winslow (1622)

title: Activision Needs to Hit the Reset Button
summary: Videogame publisher has shed a third of its market value as doubts about management's ability to fix its workplace culture have grown. It says something when the first question that now pops to mind regarding Activision Blizzard is: What is going right?

title: What's in the Roughly $2 Trillion Build Back Better Bill
summary: Proposals include universal prekindergarten, expansion of Affordable Care Act and renewable energy tax credits. The House has approved a social spending and climate bill that will cost roughly $2 trillion, down from $3.5 trillion after months of intraparty negotiations.

title: Migrants on Belarus-Poland Border Are Freezing but Won't Give Up Hope to Cross
summary: Belarusian authorities have cleared camps, but thousands are now crammed in warehouses. BRUZGI, Belarus-Thousands of migrants have been crowded into a warehouse near the border between Poland and Belarus, after Belarusian authorities coaxed them into abandoning the freezing camps they occupied for weeks in the hopes of crossing into European Union territory.

title: The Ship's Captain Died at Sea. Six Months Later, His Body Was Still in the Freezer.
summary: Resume Subscription. BUCHAREST-After 40 years at sea, on his last voyage before retirement, Captain Dan Sandu slipped into his cabin on the MV Vantage Wave, a cargo ship sailing away from India, feeling unwell. "Don't worry," he typed in what would be a final email to his wife in April. "Everything will be fine."

title: Roblox, Intuit, Farfetch, Lucid: What to Watch in the Stock Market Today
summary: Intuit lifted its financial forecast; Farfetch shares plunged after it missed sales expectations. Wall Street indexes are wavering on renewed anxiety around rising Covid-19 infections and related restrictions in Europe. Here's what we're watching in Friday's trading:

title: For Putin, the Great Prize Has Always Been Ukraine
summary: The Russian president takes pride in having restored his country's power and prominence after the Cold War, but he won't consider his legacy complete until Kyiv again becomes Moscow's satellite. For the second time this year, Western intelligence agencies have detected threatening Russian military moves along the country's border with Ukraine. According to the Ukrainian government, Moscow has amassed more than 115,000 troops, many in close proximity to the Donbas region, which is partly controlled by Russian-led forces and has been the center of an unresolved conflict for nearly eight years. Officials in the U.S. and Europe worry that Russia's actions may be a prelude to invasion.

title: For Airbus and Boeing, Inflation in Airfreight May Also Prove Temporary
summary: While financial markets expect today's profit bonanza in the shipping industry to fade, aviation executives are putting their faith in freighters. Will Covid-19 deliver a permanent boost to the cargo business? Financial markets seem less optimistic than shipping and aviation companies.

title: This Poker-Playing, Bond-Trading Orthodox Jew Is Giving All His Winnings to Charity. But Is It Kosher?
summary: Gershon Distenfeld is competing at poker's highest level despite playing just a few weeks a year. He's urging rival professional poker players to give away at least 1% of what they make.. Wall Street is full of would-be poker pros. Gershon Distenfeld, the co-head of AllianceBernstein's roughly $300 billion fixed-income investing unit, is a little different.

title: Austria Becomes First in Europe to Impose Vaccine Mandate, Return to Lockdown
summary: In a warning sign for other Western countries, the resurgence of the virus comes even though two thirds of the population have been vaccinated. Austria became the first European country to introduce a general vaccination mandate and return to a nationwide lockdown in reaction to a rapid rise in Covid-19 infections and hospitalizations despite mass immunization.

title: Women's Tennis Takes On China With Threat to Pull Its Business
summary: WTA chief executive Steve Simon has threatened to pull the tour out of the country following the disappearance of Peng Shuai. Nothing in Steve Simon's career as a tennis promoter prepared him for the crisis he is suddenly faced with this month: a player's disappearance that has forced his organization, the Women's Tennis Association, into a standoff with the Chinese government.

title: Candace Bushnell Returns to New York-This Time, Onstage
summary: The author, whose columns gave the world 'Sex and the City,' is back with an Off-Broadway show. But she's way less of a Carrie than you'd think: 'Nobody has come along and said, Let me help you do this.'. Candace Bushnell sweeps into Le Bilboquet, the Upper East Side bistro that the New York Post once called "the snobbiest joint in town," and finds a dining room packed with noisy, pretty people. The writer and now-performer is drained from seven straight days of rehearsing and performing her new one-woman show, Is There Still Sex in the City?, but the energy coursing through the lunchtime crowd seems to perk her up. So does the champagne.

title: Storms Forecast for Thanksgiving Week Could Complicate Holiday Travel Plans
summary: Weather predictions could change, but currently show rain on both coasts early next week. Inclement weather could mean travel delays for Thanksgiving week, one of the busiest of the year in the U.S.

title: Biden Administration Looks to Expand Access to Covid-19 Antiviral Pills
summary: Officials are reviewing whether Paxlovid, Pfizer's oral drug awaiting approval, can be made widely available on the commercial market. The Biden administration is exploring ways to expand access to promising Covid-19 antivirals that can keep people out of the hospital when the pills become more plentiful in coming months, according to a person familiar with the planning.

title: Why Big-Name Teams Are Firing Coaches Before Thanksgiving
summary: Coaches used to get fired at the end of the season. But 11 Division I coaches have already been pushed out in 2021, a sign of changes in college football.. It didn't matter that Virginia Tech won its game last Saturday by more than four touchdowns or that the football team was within one win of bowl eligibility. Athletic director Whit Babcock had already made a million-dollar decision. It was time to fire the coach.

title: Secret Chinese Port Project in Persian Gulf Rattles U.S. Relations With Key Ally
summary: Alarmed U.S. officials warned Emirati government, a Mideast ally, that Chinese military presence could hinder ties; construction has halted. WASHINGTON-U.S. intelligence agencies learned this spring that China was secretly building what they suspected was a military facility at a port in the United Arab Emirates, one of the U.S.'s closest Mideast allies, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Roku Plans to Develop More Than 50 Original Shows in Next Two Years
summary: Streaming-media hub looks to turn Roku Channel into destination for free content. Roku Inc., the nation's biggest pathway to streaming services, wants to become an entertainment force in its own right.

title: Former Prime Minister Convicted of Corruption Withdraws Request for Property From Malaysia
summary: Najib Razak was found guilty last year on charges related to his role in the 1MDB financial scandal; he remains free on bail while he appeals. KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia-Former Prime Minister Najib Razak, who was convicted of corruption last year for his role in one of the world's largest financial scandals, withdrew his request for a multimillion-dollar property from the Malaysian government after it sparked a clash in parliament a day earlier.

title: Blinken Says U.S. Will Treat African Nations as Equal Partners
summary: Secretary of State says Biden administration won't require governments to choose between cooperating with U.S., China or Russia. ABUJA, Nigeria-Secretary of State Antony Blinken said that the U.S. would treat African countries as equals rather than "subjects of geopolitics" in a speech meant to set out the Biden administration's policy toward the continent.

title: Biden Administration Signals Its Infrastructure Priorities With $1 Billion in Transportation Grants
summary: The awards to local governments come as the administration prepares to give out more than $100 billion in grants under the new infrastructure law. The Biden administration on Friday announced some $1 billion in transportation grants for local projects, offering clues about its spending priorities as it gets ready to allocate funds from the roughly $1 trillion infrastructure package signed into law this week.

title: 'Meet a Jew' Program Aims to Tackle German Anti-Semitism
summary: Resume Subscription. BERLIN-Sana Kisilis and Karina Markhbein sat at the front of a classroom surrounded by two dozen young adults arranged in a semicircle. For many of them, the two women were the first Jews they had ever met.

title: Cargo Pilots Leave Hong Kong Over Covid Restrictions
summary: Hong Kong has the world's No. 2 air cargo hub-and one of the tightest quarantines. HONG KONG-Air cargo operators are scrambling to square Hong Kong's tough quarantine rules with the city's role as a crucial hub for airfreight, as pandemic restrictions collide with an already tight supply chain.

title: Alibaba Stock Slides Again as Growth Prospects Ebb
summary: JD.com's shares extended their recent outperformance versus those of its Chinese e-commerce rival. A disappointing growth forecast from Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. helped push down the internet giant's shares again while those of rival JD.com Inc. shares jumped, reflecting the two Chinese e-commerce companies' diverging fortunes.

title: India to Repeal Farming Laws After Mass Protests
summary: Farmers who opposed rules worried they would herald end to regulations, subsidies and support. NEW DELHI-Prime Minister Narendra Modi said the government would abandon an effort to deregulate the agricultural sector, bowing to massive farmer protests sparked by laws passed last year and dealing a major setback to his efforts to overhaul India's economy.

title: Japan Plans $490 Billion Stimulus to Jolt Struggling Economy
summary: While U.S. frets about overheating, Tokyo is still trying to get warm. TOKYO-Japan's government approved a $490 billion package to support recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic after recent economic struggles, including cash payments to most families and some smaller companies.

title: Fed Programs Have Kept Finance Flowing to Fossil Fuels
summary: Oil-and-gas companies have logged record amounts of private-sector financing since Fed's 2020 interest-rate cuts and corporate bond-buying programs. The world's biggest banks and investors recently pledged at the Glasgow climate conference to crimp the flow of finance to fossil fuels. But the Federal Reserve's pandemic-era rescues have kept the spigot open.

title: The Best Work-From-Home-or-Office Gadgets: Boring but Useful Gifts for Hybrid Life
summary: Our Personal Tech columnists recommend headphones, printers, cord organizers and other gadgets for the new work-anywhere reality. Is there a chance that giving someone a printer, a desk-cord organizer or a bag for electronic accessories could imply you don't, you know, like that person?

title: Nigeria's Data Center Industry Taps Latest in Energy-Efficient Technology
summary: The growing sector's new construction projects aren't forced to rely on any existing infrastructure. Nigeria's fledgling data center industry reflects the benefits of a fresh start, as companies starting from scratch take advantage of more energy-efficient technology, industry executives say.

title: Business Group Challenges Lina Khan's Agenda at FTC
summary: U.S. Chamber of Commerce asserts FTC is overstepping authority under Khan; FTC says it won't back down. WASHINGTON-The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is challenging Federal Trade Commission Chairwoman Lina Khan, contending in a series of letters that she is overstepping the agency's legal authority.

title: Get These 2021 Tax Breaks Before They're Gone
summary: Making the most of these tax-code changes before year-end could reduce what you owe the IRS next April. Plan your 2021 taxes now-or else.

title: Your Index Fund Has Diamond Hands
summary: Active managers struggle to beat index funds, but they have the advantage of being able to dump obviously overvalued meme stocks, while the latter can't. Does it matter if your chairman has a small wee-wee?

title: Chinese Developer Yango Agrees to a Bond Swap With Investors
summary: New debt matures in September 2022 and pays a 10.25% coupon; investors will also get cash for the bonds they turn in. A Chinese property developer on the brink of default has received approval for a debt swap, allowing it to delay payments.

title: House Set to Approve $2 Trillion Spending Bill
summary: GOP leader McCarthy's hourslong speech prompts Democrats to delay vote until Friday morning. WASHINGTON-The House is set to pass a roughly $2 trillion education, healthcare and climate package Friday, as Democrats corralled their slim majority to approve the centerpiece of President Biden's economic agenda after months of wrangling.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.
